ORDER re 16 Stipulated Notice of Dismissal: Counsel having notified the Court of settlement of this case, and it appearing that no issue remains for the Court's determination, IT IS ORDERED that this action and all claims asserted herein are DISMISSED with prejudice and without costs to any party by Judge Ronald B. Leighton. (JAB) (Entered: 09/06/2016)

case_data.name: Disability Rights Washington v. Adkins

documents.title: Complaint
documents.text:
Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 1 of 14
 
1   
 
 
2 
 
 
3 
 
 
4 
 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
5 
WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON 
AT TACOMA 
6 
 
DISABILITY RIGHTS WASHINGTON,  No.  16-5329 
7 
   
  Plaintiff,   
8 
   
  vs.  COMPLAINT 
9 
 
SHERIFF CHUCK ATKINS, in his official 
10 
capacity; CHIEF RIC BISHOP, in his official 
capacity; COMMANDER MIKE ANDERSON, 
11 
in his official capacity, and CLARK COUNTY 
JAIL, 
12 
 
13    Defendants. 
 
14  COMES NOW Plaintiff Disability Rights Washington by and through its attorney, and as 
15  for its cause of action against Defendants Chuck Atkins, Ric Bishop, Mike Anderson, and the 
16  Clark County Jail, states and alleges as follows. 
17 
I.  PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
18  1.  This civil rights action seeks injunctive and declaratory relief to enjoin Sheriff 
19  Chuck Atkins, Chief Ric Bishop, Commander Mike Anderson, and Clark County Jail from 
20  obstructing Disability Rights Washington’s full, complete, and meaningful access to all records 
21  necessary to investigate deaths in the jail over the last year. Disability Rights Washington, the 
22  federally designated protection and advocacy system for people with disabilities in Washington 
23  State, requested records pursuant to the federal Protection and Advocacy Acts, including the 
 
COMPLAINT - 1  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 2 of 14
 
1  Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights (DD) Act of 1975, 42 U.S.C. § 15041, 
et seq., the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals With Mental Illness (PAIMI) Act, 42 U.S.C. 
2 
§ 10801, et seq., and the Protection and Advocacy for Individual Rights (PAIR) Act 29 U.S.C. § 
3 
794e, et seq., and the regulations promulgated pursuant to these statutes. Disability Rights 
4 
Washington made this request in order to investigate numerous death that have occurred at Clark 
5 
County Jail which is operated under the direction of Sheriff Atkins and the other defendants.  
6 
2.  Under federal law, Disability Rights Washington is entitled to any records 
7 
necessary to complete a full investigation, including video recordings. When an investigation 
8 
involves a death, responses must be provided immediately, no later than 24 hours from the time 
9 
of the request.  
10 
3.  In response to Disability Rights Washington’s record request, the jail has 
11 
provided written records, but refuses to provide responsive video records unless Disability 
12 
Rights Washington agrees not to share the videos with anyone. The federal law that gives 
13 
protection and advocacy systems like Disability Rights Washington access to these records does 
14 
not contain any requirement that Disability Rights Washington agree to never share records with 
15 
anyone. In fact, the federal mandates expect that Disability Rights Washington will use the 
16 
information it receives to educate and advocate.   
17 
4.  Defendants’ continued resistance to the independent scrutiny of the protection and 
18 
advocacy system though its refusal to provide the requested video is an unnecessary, 
19 
unreasonable, and unlawful restriction on Disability Rights Washington’s ability to effectively 
20 
protect the rights of people with disabilities.  
21 
   
22 
23 
 
COMPLAINT - 2  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 3 of 14
 
1  II.  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
5.  This action arises under the laws of the United States.  Plaintiff Disability Rights 
2 
Washington seeks declaratory and injunctive relief pursuant to, the DD Act, 42 U.S.C. § 15041, 
3 
the PAIMI Act, 42 U.S.C. § 10801, and the PAIR Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794e, to redress the 
4 
interference, by Defendants, in Disability Rights Washington’s ability to carry out the function 
5 
of the protection and advocacy system for Washington State by denying Disability Rights 
6 
Washington access to records that are necessary to conduct a full and meaningful investigation in 
7 
to potential abuse and neglect.   
8 
6.  Jurisdiction in this matter is asserted pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331, 2201 for 
9 
causes of action arising under the Constitution and federal statutory and common laws of the 
10 
United States. 
11 
7.  The rights which Plaintiff seeks to enforce are guaranteed by the federal 
12 
government through the mandates set forth in the DD Act, 42 U.S.C. §15041, the PAIMI Act, 42 
13 
U.S.C. § 10801, and the PAIR Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794e.  These Acts establish a mandate for 
14 
Disability Rights Washington to protect and advocate for individuals with developmental, 
15 
mental, sensory, and physical disabilities who have been abused, neglected, or had their rights 
16 
otherwise violated.   
17 
8.  This Honorable Court also has authority pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201 and 2202 
18 
to enter declaratory judgments declaring the rights and other legal relations of parties to the 
19 
action.   
20 
9.  An award of monetary damages is inadequate as plaintiff suffers and will continue 
21 
to suffer irreparable harm from defendants’ actions, inactions, policies, and procedures and the 
22 
violations complained herein.   
23 
 
COMPLAINT - 3  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 4 of 14
 
1  10.  Venue is proper pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1391(b) as all parties reside in the State 
of Washington and Plaintiff’s claim for relief arises within this state.  Defendants performed the 
2 
acts and omissions complained of herein in the State of Washington in this district.  This District 
3 
provides the most convenient forum for the litigation of these issues.   
4 
III.  PARTIES 
5 
Plaintiff  
6 
Disability Rights Washington 
7 
11.  Plaintiff Disability Rights Washington, a nonprofit corporation duly organized 
8 
under the laws of the State of Washington, is the statewide protection and advocacy system 
9 
designated by the Governor of the State of Washington to protect and advocate for the legal and 
10 
civil rights of those citizens of this state who have disabilities, pursuant to the DD Act, 42 U.S.C. 
11 
§ 15041, et seq., the PAIMI Act, 42 U.S.C. § 10801, et seq., and the PAIR Act, 29 U.S.C. § 
12 
794e.  R.C.W. 71A.10.080 (2).  DRW maintains offices in Seattle and Spokane at 315 5th 
13 
Avenue South, Suite 850, Seattle, WA 98104, and 10 N. Post Street, Spokane, WA 99201.    
14 
12.  As the duly designated statewide protection and advocacy system for individuals 
15 
with disabilities in the State of Washington, Disability Rights Washington has the authority and 
16 
responsibility to pursue legal, administrative, and such other appropriate remedies or relief as 
17 
may be necessary to protect and advocate for the rights of those persons within the State of 
18 
Washington who are, or who may be eligible for treatment, services, or habilitation due to their 
19 
physical and/or mental disabilities pursuant to the DD Act, 42 U.S.C. § 15043, the PAIMI Act, 
20 
42 U.S.C. § 108051, and the PAIR Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794e (f).   
21 
13.  In its capacity as the designated protection and advocacy system for the State of 
22 
Washington, Disability Rights Washington is entitled to access all persons with disabilities, 
23 
 
COMPLAINT - 4  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 5 of 14
 
1  individually or as a group, receiving services in the State of Washington and otherwise 
confidential records of individuals as well an any other records necessary to conduct a full 
2 
investigation in order to adequately and meaningfully protect their rights pursuant to federal and 
3 
state statutes in regard thereto.  42 C.F.R. § 51.2 
4 
14.  DRW has and will continue to suffer irreparable harm as a result of Defendants’ 
5 
actions or inactions absent preliminary and permanent relief.   
6 
Defendants 
7 
A.  Sheriff Chuck Atkins, in his official capacity 
8 
15.  Sherriff Chuck Atkins is sued in his official capacity as the elected Sherriff of 
9 
Clark County.  Defendant Atkins’s administrative office is located in Vancouver, Washington. 
10 
16.  Defendant Atkins, in his official capacity, has at all times relevant herein acted 
11 
under color of state law and has exercised general responsibility, supervision, and oversight of 
12 
the policies, practices, and operations of the Office of the Sherriff of Clark County, of which the 
13 
corrections division and jail are a part. Defendant Atkins’s responsibilities include overseeing all 
14 
staff, including those responsible for disclosure of information maintained by or otherwise 
15 
available to the jail.  
16 
B.  Chief Ric Bishop, in his official capacity 
17 
17.  Chief Ric Bishop is sued in his official capacity as the chief of the corrections 
18 
division of Clark County Sherriff’s office.  Defendant Bishop’s administrative office is located in 
19 
Vancouver, Washington. 
20 
18.  Defendant Bishop, in his official capacity, has at all times relevant herein acted 
21 
under color of state law and has exercised general responsibility, supervision, and oversight of 
22 
the policies, practices, and operations of the corrections division, of which the jail is a part.  
23 
 
COMPLAINT - 5  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 6 of 14
 
1  Defendant Bishop’s responsibilities include overseeing staff responsible for disclosure of 
information maintained by or otherwise available to the jail.  
2 
C.  Commander Mike Anderson, in his official capacity 
3 
19.  Commander Mike Anderson is sued in his official capacity as the commander of 
4 
the Clark County Jail.  Defendant Anderson’s administrative office is located in Vancouver, 
5 
Washington. 
6 
20.  Defendant Anderson, in his official capacity, has at all times relevant herein acted 
7 
under color of state law and has exercised general responsibility, supervision, and oversight of 
8 
the policies, practices, and operations of the corrections division, of which the jail is a part. 
9 
Defendant Anderson’s responsibilities include overseeing staff responsible for disclosure of 
10 
information maintained by or otherwise available to the jail.  
11 
D.  Clark County Jail 
12 
21.  Defendant Clark County Jail is a county operated correctional facility housing 
13 
people charged with crimes or serving relatively short sentences, which includes numerous 
14 
people with disabilities, many of whom require specialized services or housing to be safe. As a 
15 
jail, its staff, facilities, and infrastructure are used to create and maintain records on the services 
16 
and people it serves and the actions of staff.   
17 
IV.  FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
18 
22.  At all times relevant herein, Disability Rights Washington has been, and is, 
19 
designated by the Governor of the State of Washington as the protection and advocacy system 
20 
for those citizens of this state who have mental, developmental, and physical disabilities. 
21 
23.  Disability Rights Washington, like each of the protection and advocacy agencies 
22 
currently operating in the other forty-nine states, the federal protectorates (American Samoa, the 
23 
 
COMPLAINT - 6  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 7 of 14
 
1  Commonwealth of the North Mariana Islands, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the United States Virgin 
Islands), and the District of Columbia, operates under the mandates of the DD Act, 42 U.S.C. § 
2 
15041 et seq., the PAIMI Act, 42 U.S.C. § 10801 et seq., and the PAIR Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794e et 
3 
seq.  
4 
24.  As a result of the extensive congressional hearings preceding each of the aforesaid 
5 
statutory enactments, Congress found that there had been an extensive history of unlawful 
6 
discriminatory segregation, extraordinary maltreatment, financial exploitation, neglect, and 
7 
physical abuse of individuals with disabilities throughout the United States.  
8 
25.  The federal laws that established the protection and advocacy systems were 
9 
created in direct response to the need for independent advocacy services for individuals with 
10 
disabilities who were not getting adequate services from state operated programs. See e.g., 42 
11 
U.S.C. § 10501 (11)-(12).   
12 
26.  The Protection and Advocacy Acts (P&A Acts) require that each state, in 
13 
exchange for receipt of certain federal financial assistance, “effect a system to protect and 
14 
advocate for the rights of persons” with disabilities and further specify that these systems must 
15 
have the authority to investigate and pursue legal and other appropriate remedies for those 
16 
persons.  The DD Act, 42 U.S.C. § 15041 et seq., the PAIMI Act, 42 U.S.C. § 10801 et seq., and 
17 
the PAIR Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794e et seq.     
18 
27.  The Washington State legislature provided for such a system with the enactment 
19 
of R.C.W. 71A.10.080.  Specifically, under the provisions of R.C.W. 71A.10.080 (1), the 
20 
designated protection and advocacy agency “shall have the authority to pursue legal, 
21 
administrative, and other appropriate remedies to protect the rights of the developmentally 
22 
disabled, and to investigate allegations of abuse and neglect.”    
23 
 
COMPLAINT - 7  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 8 of 14
 
1  28.  Disability Rights Washington, in accordance with its congressional mandates, 
duties, and responsibilities as the designated protection and advocacy agency for Washington, 
2 
employs attorneys and advocates to provide protection and advocacy services to people in 
3 
Washington who have mental, developmental, physical, and sensory disabilities.   
4 
29.  Disability Rights Washington’s mandate to provide investigative and advocacy 
5 
services to individuals with disabilities extends to individuals residing in both private and 
6 
publicly-funded facilities. 
7 
30.  Defendants administer Clark County’s jail.  
8 
31.  Jails are explicitly mentioned in a non-exclusive list of setting that are considered 
9 
a facility which “may include, but need not be limited to, hospitals, nursing homes, community 
10 
facilities for individuals with mental illness, board and care homes, homeless shelters, and jails 
11 
and prisons.” 42 U.S.C.A. § 10802. 
12 
32.  Disability Rights Washington has authority to initiate an investigation when it has 
13 
probable cause to suspect people with disabilities are being abused or neglected. 
14 
33.  Disability Rights Washington’s determinations of probable cause are controlled 
15 
by federal law which states:  
16 
(g) Determination of “probable cause” may result from P&A system monitoring 
17 
or other activities, including observation by P&A system personnel, and reviews 
of monitoring and other reports prepared by others whether pertaining to 
18 
individuals with mental illness or to general conditions affecting their health or 
safety. 
19 
 
42 C.F.R. § 51.31.  
20 
34.  Here, Disability Rights Washington has relied upon its understanding of the terms 
21 
abuse and neglect as defined by the Protection and Advocacy Acts as well as its extensive 
22 
23 
 
COMPLAINT - 8  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 9 of 14
 
1  knowledge and experience with jail service delivery systems generally and its visits and review 
of records from Clark County Jail to determine it has probable cause.   
2 
35.  The federal laws that control Disability Rights Washington’s investigations define 
3 
abuse as:  
4 
any act or failure to act by an employee of a facility rendering care or treatment 
5 
which was performed, or which was failed to be performed, knowingly, 
recklessly, or intentionally, and which caused, or may have caused, injury or 
6 
death to a [sic] individual with mental illness, and includes acts such as— 
(A) the rape or sexual assault of a [sic] individual with mental illness; 
7 
(B) the striking of a [sic] individual with mental illness; 
(C) the use of excessive force when placing a [sic] individual with mental illness 
8 
in bodily restraints; and 
(D) the use of bodily or chemical restraints on a [sic] individual with mental 
9 
illness which is not in compliance with Federal and State laws and regulations.  
 
10 
42 U.S.C.A. § 10802. 
 
11 
36.  Neglect is defined as: 
12 
a negligent act or omission by any individual responsible for providing services in 
a facility rendering care or treatment which caused or may have caused injury or 
13 
death to a1 individual with mental illness or which placed a1 individual with 
mental illness at risk of injury or death, and includes an act or omission such as 
14 
the failure to establish or carry out an appropriate individual program plan or 
treatment plan for a1 individual with mental illness, the failure to provide 
15 
adequate nutrition, clothing, or health care to a [sic] individual with mental 
illness, or the failure to provide a safe environment for a [sic] individual with 
16 
mental illness, including the failure to maintain adequate numbers of 
appropriately trained staff. 
17 
42 U.S.C.A. § 10802. 
18 
 
37.  Public reports from multiple media sources indicate there have been multiple 
19 
deaths in the Clark County Jail.  
20 
38.  On March 22, 2015, Mycheal Lynch, a 32 year old Vancouver resident, died from 
21 
a homicide in Clark County Jail after a restraint incident. 
22 
http://www.columbian.com/news/2015/apr/16/clark-county-jail-inmate-death-homicide-lynch/ 
23 
 
COMPLAINT - 9  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 10 of 14
 
1  39.  On March 30, 2015, Douglas E. Mayhugh, a 35 year old Longview resident, died 
from suicide in the Clark County Jail of asphyxia due to hanging. 
2 
http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/inmates-death-in-clark-county-jail-is-ruled-a-suicide-
3 
by-hanging/ 
4 
40.  On February 27, 2016, Daniel J. Fisher, a 33 year old Vancouver resident, died 
5 
from suicide in the Clark County Jail of asphyxia due to hanging. 
6 
http://www.oregonlive.com/pacific-northwest-
7 
news/index.ssf/2016/04/clark_county_jail_reports_seco.html 
8 
41.  In light of these deaths of inmates who may have needed additional services to 
9 
avoid homicide and suicide in the Clark County Jail, and in conjunction with previous records it 
10 
had received from Defendants regarding suicides in previous years and jail policies, and an on-
11 
site visit to the facility on March 7, 2016 in which Disability Rights Washington attorneys and 
12 
staff interviewed jail staff and inmates, and took video and photographic recordings of various 
13 
jail settings, Disability Rights Washington determined it had probable cause to suspect possible 
14 
abuse and neglect of individuals with disabilities affected by Defendants services or lack thereof.   
15 
42.  On April 13, Disability Rights Washington sent a request for: 
16 
1. List of inmate deaths from 3/31/2015 to present, names of said inmates, and the 
17 
determined causes of death;  
18 
2. Jail records, inmate health records, and any other investigative records of the 
inmate who died after restraint in March of 2015;  
19 
3. Jail records, inmate health records, and any other investigative records of the 
20 
inmate who died from suicide on 3/30/2015;  
21 
4. Jail records, inmate health records, and any other investigative records of the 
inmate who died from suicide on 2/27/2016;  
22 
5. Jail records, inmate health records, and any other investigative records of 
23  additional inmates, if any, who died from suicide between 3/30/2015 and 
present;  
 
COMPLAINT - 10  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 11 of 14
 
1  6. The names and contact information of the individuals who have attempted to 
commit suicide, and, if applicable, the legal guardian of each individual who 
attempted to commit suicide while being detained at Clark County Jail from 
2 
1/1/2015 to present; and  
3 
7. Any updated jail policies or procedures regarding suicide precautions, 
assessment, and screening since March of 2015.  
4 
5  43.  That request informed Defendants that the definition of records included “written 
6  or in another medium, draft or final, including handwritten notes, electronic files, photographs or 
7  video or audio tape records….” 42 C.F.R. § 51.41(c) (emphasis added). 
8  44.  The request also informed Defendants that federal statute provides 24 hours to 
9  respond.  
10  45.  Defendants have provided written records, but refuse to provide video records 
11  unless Disability Rights Washington agrees to not show anyone else the videos.  
12  46.  It is now three weeks since that request was made, and subsequent to that request 
13  another death occurred in Clark County jail. 
14  47.  On April 22, 2016, Dustin M. Graves, a 23 year old Battle Ground resident, died 
15  from suicide in the Clark County Jail of asphyxia due to hanging. 
16  http://www.columbian.com/news/2016/apr/25/clark-county-jail-suicide-victim-idd-as-battle-
17  ground-man/ 
18  48.  This delay highlights the urgency of timely production of records as Defendants 
19  continue to operate a correctional facility and serve countless people with disabilities every day.  
20  49.  Disability Rights Washington attempted to resolve this issue without resorting to 
21  litigation over several phone and email exchanges with Defendants’ counsel. See e.g. Letter from 
22  David Carlson , Director of Legal Advocacy, Disability Rights Washington, to Jane Vetto, 
23 
 
COMPLAINT - 11  Disability Rights Washington 
  315 5th Avenue South, Suite 850 
 
Seattle, Washington   98104 
(206) 324-1521    Fax: (206) 957-0729  
 

Case 3:16-cv-05329-RBL   Document 1   Filed 05/04/16   Page 12 of 14
 
1  Senior Deputy Prosecuting Attorney, Civil Division Clark County Prosecutor’s Office (May 3, 
2016) a true and correct copy of which is attached as Exhibit 1.  
2 
50.  As a result of Defendants’ refusal to follow federal law, DRW has been denied 
3 
access to conduct a full and meaningful investigation and has been unable to fulfill its federal 
4 
mandate to investigate possible abuse and neglect of individuals with disabilities. 
5 
51.  Defendants not only refuse to provide the video without restrictions on how 
6 
Disability Rights Washington may use it, Defendants also refuse to provide their actual reason 
7 
for denial or delay as required by federal law. 42 CFR § 51.43.  Instead their written response is: 
8 
“The Jail videos are different from other records and unrestricted release of those records 
9 
exposes guards and inmates to unacceptable risks.” See Email string terminating in email from 
10 
Stacie Siebrecht, Associate Director of Legal Advocacy, Disability Rights Washington, to Chris 
11 
Horne, Chief Civil Deputy Prosecuting Attorney, Civil Division Clark County Prosecutor’s 
12 
Office (May 3, 2016) a true and correct copy of which is attached as Exhibit 2. There is no 
13 
factual support for Defendants’ conclusion and most importantly, no legal support for violating 
14 
federal law.   
15 
52.  Defendants have been made aware of Disability Rights Washington’s federal 
16 
authority to obtain relevant videos, when Disability Rights Washington is investigating abuse 
17 
and neglect.  
18 
53.  Defendants’ refusal to provide the videos frustrate the federally mandated 
19 
functions and duties of the protection and advocacy system.  As described in the foregoing 
20 
paragraphs, Plaintiff attempted, on multiple occasions, to resolve its access issue with the 
21 
Defendants.  These attempts have proven unsuccessful.   
22 
23 
 
COMPLAINT - 12  Disability Rights Washington

statutory interests in investigating abuse and neglect.

55.  Plaintiff has standing to bring this action on its own behalf, because the refusal of 
3 
access by Defendants constitutes an injury in fact to Plaintiff’s legally-protected interests.  This 
4 
injury is concrete, particularized, actual, and imminent.  There is a causal relationship between 
5 
the injury and Defendants’ challenged conduct, and a favorable decision by this Court will 
6 
address the injury.  
7 
56.  Plaintiff has no adequate remedy at law.   
8

42 U.S.C. § 10801 et seq., and 29 U.S.C. § 794e.
